thread.title: Daugaard Answers Questions On GEAR UP
thread.title_full: Daugaard Answers Questions On GEAR UP

title: Daugaard Answers Questions On GEAR UP
text:
Daugaard Answers Questions On GEAR UP October 2, 2015, 6:00 PM by Angela Kennecke SALEM, SD - 
Friday, we tracked down Governor Dennis Daugaard to ask about the financial troubles surrounding GEAR UP. 
The state got $16.5 million in federal grant money over a decade to run the program, which was turned over to Mid Central Educational Cooperative. 
A KELOLAND News investigation uncovered that the two non-profit groups being given the money from Mid Central to run the program were both formed by Scott Westerhuis. 
Angela Kennecke: "Are you concerned that that money may not have all gone where it was intended--for the purposes of helping Native American students?" Governor Dennis Daugaard: "I think the tragedy that happened after the GEAR UP grant was not renewed, causes us all to worry about the financial side of things." 
Governor Dennis Daugaard says the state is providing documents to DCI investigators to help answer questions after Mid Central's troubled audit. 
"It did not indicate any criminal activity. And of course the Department of Criminal Investigation is investigating that. We're assisting with that and I'm hopeful we'll find out more about it," Gov. Daugaard said. 
Angela Kennecke: "Will the state go back now and look at what happened over the last decade, in previous years to see if there were similar problems with the handling of the money and the grant funds?" Governor Daugaard: “We’ve already asked the Department of Education and the Department of Legislative Audit to consider looking at all the different contracts we had with Mid Central." 
When asked if the State Department of Education should have had more oversight -- Daugaard says the DOE was trusting Mid Central with the money. 
"As a general rule, we had not had problems in South Dakota contracting with government entities--they're among the most trustworthy. Whether there's been an exception here and there's been wrongdoing--we'll learn," Daugaard said. 
Angela Kennecke: "What about going back a decade--8 or 9 years--and taking a look over these past several years at the GEAR UP grant specifically?" Governor Daugaard: "There's no plan to do that right now." 
In a letter to the legislative audit committee, Daugaard says that the current ongoing legislative audit of Mid Central is expected to go to the audit committee later this month. Daugaard says he's also asked Attorney General Marty Jackley to look into any evidence of wrongdoing in the administration of GEAR UP. 
Stacy Phelps has resigned from the State Board of Education. Phelps, who administered GEAR UP, also ran Scott Westerhuis' American Indian Institute for Innovation. 
Phelps was also listed as the president of Westerhuis' consulting firm. Gov. Daugaard said that Phelps' involvement with GEAR UP would have been a distraction for the board.
